segment.source: Identify File Types, Files, and Folders (Windows 10)
segment.target: Identify File Types, Files, and Folders (Windows 10)

segment.source: Identify File Types, Files, and Folders
segment.target: Identify File Types, Files, and Folders

segment.source: Identify File Types, Files, and Folders
segment.target: Identify File Types, Files, and Folders

segment.source: When planning for your migration, if not using MigDocs.xml, you should identify the file types, files, folders, and settings that you want to migrate.
segment.target: When planning for your migration, if not using MigDocs.xml, you should identify the file types, files, folders, and settings that you want to migrate.

segment.source: First, you should determine the standard file locations on each computer, such as My Documents.
segment.target: First, you should determine the standard file locations on each computer, such as My Documents.

segment.source: , C:Data , and company-specified locations, such as EngineeringDrafts.
segment.target: , C:Data , and company-specified locations, such as EngineeringDrafts.

segment.source: Next, you should determine and locate the non-standard locations.
segment.target: Next, you should determine and locate the non-standard locations.

segment.source: For non-standard locations, consider the following:
segment.target: For non-standard locations, consider the following:

segment.source: File types.
segment.target: File types.

segment.source: Consider which file types need to be included and excluded from the migration.
segment.target: Consider which file types need to be included and excluded from the migration.

segment.source: You can create this list based on common applications used in your organization.
segment.target: You can create this list based on common applications used in your organization.

segment.source: Applications normally use specific file name extensions.
segment.target: Applications normally use specific file name extensions.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft Office Word primarily uses .doc, .docx and .dotx file name extension.
segment.target: For example, Microsoft Office Word primarily uses .doc, .docx and .dotx file name extension.

segment.source: However, it also uses other file types, such as templates (.dot files), on a less frequent basis.
segment.target: However, it also uses other file types, such as templates (.dot files), on a less frequent basis.

segment.source: Excluded locations.
segment.target: Excluded locations.

segment.source: Consider the locations on the computer that should be excluded from the migration (for example, %WINDIR% and Program Files).
segment.target: Consider the locations on the computer that should be excluded from the migration (for example, %WINDIR% and Program Files).

segment.source: New locations.
segment.target: New locations.

segment.source: Decide where files should be migrated to on the destination computer for example, My Documents, a designated folder, or a folder matching the files' name and location on the source computer.
segment.target: Decide where files should be migrated to on the destination computer for example, My Documents, a designated folder, or a folder matching the files' name and location on the source computer.

segment.source: For example, you might have shared data on source machine or you might wish to clean up documents outside the user profiles on the source system.
segment.target: For example, you might have shared data on source machine or you might wish to clean up documents outside the user profiles on the source system.

segment.source: Identify any data that needs to be redirected to a new location in the apply phase.
segment.target: Identify any data that needs to be redirected to a new location in the apply phase.

segment.source: This can be accomplished with location modify rules.
segment.target: This can be accomplished with location modify rules.

segment.source: Once you have verified which files and file types that the end users work with regularly, you will need to locate them.
segment.target: Once you have verified which files and file types that the end users work with regularly, you will need to locate them.

segment.source: Files may be saved to a single folder or scattered across a drive.
segment.target: Files may be saved to a single folder or scattered across a drive.

segment.source: A good starting point for finding files types to include is to look at the registered file types on the computer.
segment.target: A good starting point for finding files types to include is to look at the registered file types on the computer.

segment.source: To find the registered file types on a computer running Windows 7 or Windows 8
segment.target: To find the registered file types on a computer running Windows 7 or Windows 8

segment.source: Click Start.
segment.target: Click Start.

segment.source: Open Control Panel, click Control Panel Home, and click Programs.
segment.target: Open Control Panel, click Control Panel Home, and click Programs.

segment.source: Click Default Programs, and click Associate a file type or protocol with a program.
segment.target: Click Default Programs, and click Associate a file type or protocol with a program.

segment.source: On this screen, the registered file types are displayed.
segment.target: On this screen, the registered file types are displayed.

segment.source: For more information about how to change the file types, files, and folders that are migrated when you specify the MigUser.xml file, see User State Migration Tool (USMT) How-to topics.
segment.target: For more information about how to change the file types, files, and folders that are migrated when you specify the MigUser.xml file, see User State Migration Tool (USMT) How-to topics.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Determine What to Migrate
